Posts.Content: Sep 8, 2008 07:48PM ginger2345 wrote: I had mammosite radiation but no dummy cath was placed. I did have the cathetar in about 5 days before the treatments began however due to scheduling. I think the docs are very concerned about infection and the 2 week wait would seem unacceptable to the surgeon!! I'd call the office and make sure the appointment desk understood your situation. If she can't move you up herself, make sure she passes your concerns along to the surgeon. It should take only about an hour to place the mammosite balloon! The cathetar will be uncomfortable for the whole time to some degree and you probably won't be swinging your arms around or lifting them high over your head. I did get in the bathtub to bathe for the first time in years and made sure no water got near my breast/incision. I washed my hair too without getting the area wet, keeping a thin plastic tablecloth cut to the appropriate size around my neck. Good luck with your treatments.

Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2013 09:11PM ginger2345 wrote: With digital you don't get your results necessarily sooner; the images are immediate for the radiologist. But the rad still will want to compare to old films to detect changes, and the report then goes to the ordering doc who is the one to get back to you. The rad may come and talk to you at the time of the mammo but that usually means you need further study and that's arranged then or, if you wish, later. I understand the waiting game after a bad experience. I've had bc in the same breast twice with an 8 year interval of normal mammos. Just as I was beginning to relax about the yearly mammo, up popped another cancer. If your insurance covers mammos, which it should, it'll cover a screening digital mammo. It's when the screening turns to diagnostic that coverage may change.

Posts.Content: Apr 28, 2008 07:44PM ginger2345 wrote: The 6 month US followup is to see if there are changes or stability in your breast. Stability indicates no active changing cells to question the benign results of the biopsy. If stable, then you might go back to the yearly checkups. By all means, do the 6month US.

Posts.Content: Apr 19, 2010 11:22AM ginger2345 wrote: You're right ALH is not cancer. Your doc wants you to see the onc and, if he/she recommends it, take tamoxifen as a preventive as your risk for breast ca is increased. Primary care physicians can handle tamox too so don't freak because of the onc part. It is kinda weird sitting in the onc office with people who have invasive breast ca and other ca's like pancreatic, lung etc. I did it briefly for DCIS. But just because you're there doesn't mean you have ca. The onc might discuss the bc pills and the endometriosis risk and the risks if you're on tamox for bc prevention and help you with something there too. Go, get the onc's take on what you should do.
Posts.Title: ALH is NOT cancer, right? keiko tgood02

Posts.Content: Nov 12, 2008 07:05AM ginger2345 wrote: My radiologist suggested a stereotactic biopsy for microcalcifications. The PCP signed the order and my biopsy came back DCIS before I ever saw a surgeon. Stereotactic not excisional biopsy is the usual procedure for examining microcalcifications. Are you sure about the excisional? Your appointment with the surgeon is probably just that--an appointment to decide how to proceed, not a procedure. However,the appointment could be for the stereotactic biopsy if the surgeon performs them, then those results would dictate the next step. I'd go to that appointment and get answers to my questions including the need for MRI. Insurance companies are stingey about MRIs largely because of the large number of false positives leading to unnecessary treatment. So do check with your insurance company. Our radiologists actually do the checking for us. A BIRAD 4 gives you a really good chance for benign. Here's hoping.

Posts.Content: Nov 15, 2007 11:00AM ginger2345 wrote: One rule of "thumb"--try to get a surgeon who does at least 100 breast surgeries a year. Most of them will belong to the American College of Breast Surgeons indicating a special interest in breast surgery.
Posts.Title: Who Should I Be Seeing? Heather_Hu SandyinSoCal

Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2013 09:37AM ginger2345 wrote: Receiving your results usually creates lots of concerns and questions, and those aren't something that a nurse or secretary can answer. Or that a doctor can answer in a short phone call. You want a full discussion about your results when you first hear them. And I like to look at my doc's facial expression and body language when I get my results. If you can't get a full discussion when you first hear your results, you'll be even more anxious unless it's a simple "benign."  Even with benign, you could have followup questions. That's why most docs want to meet with the patient to personally discuss the results. Keeping busy with other things and not doing research until you know what you're dealing with is a good idea. Hoping for benign results for you, Candy.

Posts.Content: Feb 15, 2013 03:24PM ginger2345 wrote: Huntlee, You certainly deserve to know why this PS thinks you're not a candidate for the one step. The only concern I read in your post would be about the scars you have. If those scar areas need to be removed (my lumpectomy scar from 8 years earlier was the starting point for removing my breast tissue) maybe the PS thinks you won't have enough skin to immediately place over the implant, and skin will need to be stretched slowly with the TEs. You need a skin sparing mast to be able to do the immed implant. Just a guess. Ask the current PS and if his explanation doesn't seem right to you, get a second opinion. Good luck.
Posts.Title: One stage implant breast reconstruction vs. TE route Speedy4 Huntlee

Posts.Content: Feb 14, 2013 08:08PM ginger2345 wrote: I did the one step direct implant vs tissue expanders mostly because I'd save myself some time and get back to normal faster. And that's what happened and I'm glad I did that. The down side is you're being stretched all at once instead of gradually, so the pain level is higher for a couple of weeks. The other thing to keep in mind is that the one step is often more than one step. Mine was 2 trips to the OR. I always knew I'd go a second time to get the lift on the other side, but the surgeon doesn't always get the perfect amount shaped out for the PS and the PS had to remodel and do a fat graft to move some tissue for a better shape. I am really pleased with my result and the pain level was doable.

Posts.Content: Dec 1, 2007 12:04PM ginger2345 wrote: I think the doc's office like to be optimistic with the hope you'll fall into the 80% benign at core needle biopsy. That is a big number. Plain atypia wouldn't usually be enough to cause doc's to rush to excisional biopsy, but if you had ADH that would be a different story. Around my part of the country, ADH almost always calls for excisional biopsy to rule out DCIS or other malignancy is present. ADH and DCIS keep fairly close company. That said, remember the 80% benign.

Frankly, if you have a PCP-type doc, gyn-fp-internist, he/she's the one that's handling most of your care and can see beyond your bc--and most of us will die of something else. Keep your PCP in the loop. After a year, I think the radonc is superfulous.

Posts.Content: Oct 17, 2008 04:00PM ginger2345 wrote: The anti-hormone therapies come under the technical name of SERM: selective estrogen receptor modulators. So the onc may use that term. There's 2 basic categories here: Tamoxifen is one and a group of drugs called aromatase inhibitors is the other. Tamoxifen blocks the estrogen receptors so that any more cancer cells can't grab on there and make trouble, and the aromatase inhibitors deplete the body of estrogen. There are side effects to each type that the onc will discuss with you. And given your mother's personal health history, one may be perferable over the other. I hope your onc visit goes well and having a bit of info before getting there may help in understanding what can be somewhat complex. I'm sure your mother appreciates your help and is thankful that you will be with her.

Posts.Content: May 31, 2009 10:52AM ginger2345 wrote: Some women like seeing multiple docs as it gives them more security that nothing is awry on the bc front. I see my PCP only and only once a year. She covers all my breast concerns, but more importantly, she handles the problems that likely will be bigger issues in the years ahead--heart disease will be more prominent for most of us. The onc doesn't do that either. So if the PCP seems bc aware and concerned and are knowledgeable about SERMs or AIs, she may be the only doc you need. Otherwise, an onc and a PCP might be the only 2 docs needed. As for the surgeon, I let her go after a couple of checks, but some patients still follow with her. I think it's your choice. But remember, bc isn't the only problem we face as we age.

Posts.Title: Should I be less worried! koshka1 koshka1

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2009 03:56PM ginger2345 wrote: You're dealing with the same thing actually! It's about what they find on the path report. If your tissue remains "benign" after the surgical procedure, it's an excisional biopsy. If you would have a cancer of any stage, it's a lumpectomy. If your "lump" wasn't a lump, but rather microcalcifications and comes back as DCIS or an invasive cancer, then your procedure would be a partial mastectomy. A local will be fine for the surgery. That's what I did. I didn't have any of the twilight sleep type anesthesia either and was able to skip the recovery room and get food and home faster. Good luck and hope your results are benign.
Posts.Title: Lumpectomyv.Excisional Biopsy to remove entire - difference? Sock Sock

Posts.Content: Feb 15, 2008 04:04PM - edited Feb 15, 2008 04:06PM by ginger2345 A new twist to the debate: The Feb. 25, 2008, edition of Archives of Internal Medicine/vol 168 (No.4) contains an article entitled: "Estrogen Plus Progestin and Breast Cancer Detection by Means of Mammography and Breast Biopsy." This was a study of 16600 postmenopausal women over more than a 5 year period. It concluded: "Use of conjugated equine estrogens plus medroxyprogesterone acetate for approximately 5 years resulted in more than 1 in 10 and 1 in 25 women having otherwise avoidable mammogram abnormalities and breast biopsies, respectively, and compromised the diagnostic performance of both. This adverse effect on breast cancer detection should be incorporated into risk-benefit discussions with women considering even short-term combined hormone therapy." Part of the study participants received the drug and part received the placebo. Noted is that the study was stopped when the WHI Data Safety and Monitoring Board determined that more risks than benefits were associated with the use of conjugated equine estrogens plus medroxyprogesterone acetate. Another chink in the armor of HRT.
